Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Negotiating identity and building the landscape: 3rd millennium BC mortuary traditions in Bronze Age Oman

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the National Science Foundation, Drs. Kimberly Williams and Lesley Gregoricka will conduct three field seasons of bioarchaeological and geospatial research on Early Bronze Age (ca. 3100-2000 BC) mortuary sites in northern Oman. This study seeks to investigate shifts in mortuary traditions over time -- including (a) the construction of monumental tombs, (b) the geographic origins of the individuals interred within these structures, and (c) tomb placement on the landscape -- as a reflection of changing perceptions of rural identity in response to growing interregional interaction with urban areas. As a highly visible burial center at the crossroads of these interregional trade routes, the Al Khubayb Necropolis provides a unique opportunity to examine these temporal changes during a formative period of transition in the Oman Peninsula, in part by recognizing the importance of Transitional tomb forms.

The research objective is to evaluate these tombs as symbols of the changing socioeconomic roles of these Early Bronze Age communities, as rural areas increasingly engaged with large urban centers to provide them with much-desired resources, including copper. As engagement in interregional exchange networks increased, local social hierarchies would have developed, causing conflict between traditional, kin-based tribal factions and those with increasing power over aspects of trade and monument construction. Such conflict in group identity will be visible in the form of conflicting mortuary customs simultaneously attempting to promote and suppress social differentiation.

This study also posits that increasingly complex exchange networks will result in significant variability in strontium and oxygen isotopic signatures (incorporated via diet into the teeth of the individuals who lived and died in the Early Bronze Age), not only because of increased regional mobility between the interior of the peninsula and the coast (due to the mining and transport of copper), but also because of emerging interregional economic ties with the larger Persian Gulf.
Correspondingly, this project seeks to identify broader shifts in isotopic variation between early and later periods as a correlate of regional and interregional mobility associated with changing forms of social organization and definitions of group identity.

The goal of this research program is to provide new perspectives on the question of identity formation in the periphery. This will be accomplished not by focusing on the intensively studied end-points of trade, such as Mesopotamia and the Indus Valley, but in the hinterlands of Oman, where goods were actively processed and trade carried out. Much research in the past has focused on the interaction of large, core power brokers with one another; this research will be transformative because of its focus on a relatively invisible rural people, whose existence as semi-nomadic pastoralists is poorly understood. As opposed to viewing changing mortuary and mobility patterns as wholly defined by the influence of interregional exchange with urban areas including Mesopotamia, such an approach takes agency into account by focusing on the adaptations of local communities to the social hierarchies that developed from exposure to these trade systems.

The broader impacts of this study include the education and training of local Omanis as part of building a more successful program of archaeological heritage in Oman. Additionally, this project is committed to increasing student diversity and providing learning and research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students. Students will not only receive training in bioarchaeological field techniques but will also be involved in all aspects of inquiry, including sample preparation, chemical and geospatial analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project sought to provide new perspectives on the question of identity formation through the examination of Bronze Age mortuary practices and funerary landscape production on the Oman Peninsula.  In pursuit of these goals, excavation and survey were conducted in Dhank, Oman. These excavations and survey resulted in human skeletal remains and associated material culture which were analyzed under the auspices of this award, as well as data regarding mortuary monuments – both with regard to their construction and spatiality. The human skeletal remains were dated and isotopic analyses were conducted as the result of collaboration with NSF Award #1318019 (see “B” below).

A. NSF Award #1321203 accomplished the following goals:

1) three field seasons of both excavation and survey work

2) excavation of 18 mortuary monuments

3) mapping and recording of more than 1,000 mortuary monuments

4) analyses of mortuary monument spatiality.

 

These activities produced the following initial key findings: 

1) Demonstration of the usefulness of bioarchaeological research of human skeletal remains of the Oman Peninsula:  Bronze Age human skeletal remains have long been thought to provide only limited information regarding ancient lifeways on the Oman Peninsula. This work demonstrates that far more can be learned from these ancient remains than previously thought. Work conducted under this grant demonstrated that skilled excavation can result in data regarding body placement/treatment, as well as important demographic data regarding these past people.

2) New information about Hafit/Umm an-Nar period mortuary traditions: The dramatic transition in mortuary ritual observed between the Hafit and Umm an-Nar periods is still an area where significant research is necessary. Research funded by this grant helps to elucidate important specific changes that occurred during a transitional period between the Hafit and Umm an-Nar periods. These data include the use of symbolic faunal materials in the mortuary ritual and the pattern of reuse of the monuments.   

3) New information regarding Bronze Age mortuary monument architectural variation: This research contributes to the body of knowledge regarding the form and function of mortuary monuments used during the transitional period between the Hafit and Umm an-Nar periods. Specifically, we have identified variation in the construction of these monuments during this time, contributing to our growing understanding of how human identity changed during this time and was reflected in monument building.

4) New information about Bronze Age mortuary monument spatiality: Related to the variation in the construction of Bronze Age mortuary monuments, the space where these monuments were built was also examined. This work helps researchers to understand land use, the construction of mortuary landscapes, and the relationships between ancient cemeteries from multiple periods of time.

This award trained 36 students (30 undergraduates and 6 graduate students). Students were trained in archaeological field methods, geospatial analyses and survey, and osteological analyses.

 

B. Biogeochemical analyses associated with NSF Award #1318019 revealed that despite the transitional nature of funerary practices prior to the Umm an-Nar period, isotopic signatures (strontium, oxygen, and carbon) from the dental enamel of those Bronze Age individuals interred in both Hafit-type cairns and Transitional Tower Tombs did not change significantly or exhibit marked variability over time.  These data fail to support our initial hypothesis that a decrease in isotopic variability would occur as populations became increasingly sedentary and more invested in the landscape.  Instead, remarkable consistency over time in these isotopic ratios suggests that despite the increased time and labor invested in the construction of the mortuary landscape in the desert interior of Oman, local communities continued to exploit the surrounding landscape in much the same way throughout the Early Bronze Age, preserving comparable patterns of mobility, consuming similar foods, and obtaining water from isotopically similar sources.  Such consistency may speak to efforts to maintain a more traditional way of life despite temporal changes in social organization and growing complexity. 

This award trained 18 undergraduate students in enamel sample extraction and chemical preparation techniques for radiogenic strontium and stable oxygen and carbon isotope analysis.  Students were involved in both basic sample preparation activities (including stirring and centrifuging samples, desiccation) as well as more complicated laboratory procedures (including acid bath submergence, supernatant extraction, and rinsing cycles).
